description: A Freddie Mac report finds a greater share of homeowners refinancing into shorter-term loans, and a modest number pulling cash out of their homes.
title: Refinancing to Increase Equity
title_page: Refinancing to Increase Equity - The New York Times
text:
A greater share of homeowners are refinancing into shorter-term loans, while the number pulling cash out of their homes remains modest.
The two trends are helping to bolster home equity, which, thanks to rising home values, grew by $3 trillion nationally in the two previous years to the second quarter of 2014, according to the most recent quarterly refinance report from Freddie Mac.
Of the borrowers who refinanced in the third quarter of this year, 36 percent took shorter-term loans, a relatively high proportion, said Frank E. Nothaft, the chief economist for Freddie Mac. Interest in 15-year loans has remained high for the last year, in fact, largely because of financial incentives.
“The spread between the rate on a 30- and 15-year fixed has been unusually wide,” Mr. Nothaft explained. “Over the first nine months of 2014, it averaged almost a full percentage point. So if you’re able to handle the bigger payment on a 15-year, you can lower your rate by an extra percentage point.”
